Numpy Notes: Part 1

15 Aug 2014

The notes listed here are from the book "Numpy Beginner's Guide, 2nd Edition by Ivan Idris". I would recommend this book for anyone wanting to learn Numpy for Data Analysis.

Numpy has a multi-dimensional array object called ndarray. It consists of two parts: (1) the actual data; (2) some metadata describing the data. The majority of array operations leave the raw data untouched. The only aspect that changes is the metadata. The numpy array is in general homogeneous.

Array Creation and Manipulation:

  • .dtype

    this attribute gives the dtype of the array.

  • .shape

    this attribute gives the shape of the array. It returns a tuple. 

  • arange(value)

    creates a 1d numpy array. We can create a multi-dimensional array by putting the arange() function in a list. For example: 

a = array([arange(3), arange(3)])

will generate a 2 x 3 matrix.

  • The selection of elements in a given array is just like the slicing in Python.

  • The conversion datatype function in Numpy is similar to Python.

  • Another way to convert a dtype of an array is to use the character code such as: 

    arange(7, dtype='f')
    This will generate a float array of 7 elements. 

  • .reshape()

    attribute allows to create a numpy array of a certain dimension. 

  • ravel()

    flattens a matrix to 1D 

  • flatten()

    does the same as ravel() but always allocates new memory while the ravel() does not.

  • The shape of the array can also be changed with a tuple. For example: 

b.shape = (6,4)

Note that a numpy array is mutable. 

  • .transpose()

    allows to tranpose a matrix 

  • .resize()

    allows to change the dimensions of the matrix

Stacking

  • The horizontal stack, 

    hstack((a,b))
    allows to stack the matrices a and b side-by-side. This is achieved similarly with the 
    concatenate((a, b), axis = 1)

  • The vertical stack, 

    vstack((a,b))
    allows to stack the matrices a and b one over the other. This is achieved similarly with the 
    concatenate((a, b), axis = 0)

  • Depth stack, 

    dstack((a,b))
    stacks the matrices a and b depth-wise. This means stacking of list of arrays along the third axis.

  • Column stack, 

    column_stack()
    is identical to horizontal stack

  • Row stack, 

    row_stack()
    is identical to vertical stack
